channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Turkey has agreed to allow Sweden and Finland to join NATO, ending a dispute that slowed an expansion of the alliance https://t.co/ARq0KzH644

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky spoke with the head of NATO about Ukraine’s need to shore its defenses against Russian missile strikes ahead of the NATO summit. Follow the latest news on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/aUPLfeoUqT
Ghislaine Maxwell was sentenced to 20 years in prison for helping Jeffrey Epstein sexually abuse underage girls https://t.co/gWvcLnselO

Trump lunged at a Secret Service agent and tried to grab the steering wheel when his security detail refused to drive him to the Capitol on Jan. 6, former aide Cassidy Hutchinson said https://t.co/CWavo2dq5A
Instagram, TikTok and Snapchat could get sued for hooking children on their apps under a first-of-its-kind bill making its way through the California Legislature https://t.co/jMZpkUCd3e
G-7 leaders are expected to agree to start work on a mechanism to cap the purchase price of Russian oil and a new round of sanctions against Moscow https://t.co/1g5g0qxF9D
The G-7 condemns the Russian missile strike of a Ukrainian shopping mall as a war crime as NATO leaders prepare to meet in Madrid https://t.co/mLxJSjtYdM

The World Health Organization has urged countries to take measures to slow the spread of monkeypox, but on Saturday said the outbreak does not at this point constitute a global health emergency https://t.co/aIOqtK8gTH

A New York City law that would have allowed noncitizens to vote in local elections was struck down Monday by a Staten Island judge who said the measure violates the state constitution https://t.co/33DpoBri3b

G-7 leaders are meeting in Germany to discuss the war in Ukraine, plans to adopt new sanctions against Moscow and an infrastructure project to challenge China #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/DQScjiJNVm https://t.co/AUv5XJGvrN

The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that a public high school must let a football coach pray at the 50-yard line after games (corrects an earlier tweet, which has been deleted, that incorrectly stated the coach lost his job after praying) https://t.co/Yjx7qi79s2 https://t.co/L5NAByiIEU
What to Listen to This Summer: Beyoncé́, Drake, Lizzo, Burna Boy, Bad Bunny and more offer sizzling tunes that make you want to move https://t.co/D1Sj1C554D
A 44-acre private island in Alaska is hitting the market for $20 million https://t.co/9cdayCZzVV
The U.S. has carried out an airstrike in Syria that killed a suspected militant leader affiliated with al Qaeda, the U.S. military said https://t.co/E7CAUm20sR
Sit-down restaurant chains are looking for ways to raise menu prices without scaring off diners https://t.co/vykqBRSRl0
A 44-acre private island in Alaska is hitting the market for $20 million https://t.co/9hoZ98xVtD
A paperwork error made in the 1940s robbed a World War II veteran and D-Day survivor of his medals. Nearly 80 years later, the Army is fixing its mistake. https://t.co/EHtfaJgADW
At least 40 people were found dead near San Antonio in what officials believe to be a migrant-smuggling attempt https://t.co/VHBye3nB9a

From @WSJopinion: Now is the time to expose Chinese corruption, writes Nate Sibley. A steady stream of graft scandals could help erode the Communist Party’s domestic legitimacy. https://t.co/Spb9CZwhmd

The number of people found dead Monday in a tractor trailer near San Antonio has risen to at least 46, the highest number of fatalities ever in a suspected migrant smuggling operation in the U.S., federal officials said https://t.co/oewdd6RgUp

Ocean explorers found a World War II-era U.S. Navy ship more than 22,000 feet underwater off the coast of the Philippines’s Samar Island, in what they say is the deepest shipwreck ever surveyed and identified https://t.co/0a9U4WMU3f
Ukraine is looking to recapture a city crucial for its economy and stop Russian designs on advancing to the doorstep of Europe https://t.co/KN40p5nedi
Breaking: Russian missiles hit a shopping mall in central Ukraine with around 1,000 civilians inside, killing at least 10 people, authorities said https://t.co/Gf6aYBSO8c
Credit Suisse was found guilty of helping a crime ring launder money related to cocaine trafficking in a Swiss court. A former employee was also convicted. https://t.co/U4pBL4EqaN

From @WSJopinion: The fury of the left’s reaction isn’t merely about guns and abortion. It reflects their grief at having lost the Court as the vehicle for achieving policy goals they can’t get through legislatures. https://t.co/Bz41pJR0PL

The U.S. plans to announce it will provide Ukraine with an advanced missile system and more artillery support, a senior official said. Follow the latest updates on the war in Ukraine and the G-7 summit. https://t.co/bEJOP9fbZZ

From @WSJopinion: Donald Trump and Joe Biden both face rejection, writes @Peggynoonannyc. The Jan. 6 hearings are helping Republicans solve their problem. It’s unclear what Democrats will do. https://t.co/RMoZNDe56E

The trial of WNBA star Brittney Griner formally began in Russia on Monday. In a closed-door hearing, the court extended her detention on drug charges by six months, through Dec. 20. https://t.co/qfoGrJ464A
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/qCwsfHtg1G https://t.co/lzIg3CIP9O
Employers say a lot of office chatter revolves around surging household costs. https://t.co/2lWYTjP2q4

Google suspended an engineer who contended that an artificial-intelligence chatbot the company developed had become sentient, telling him that he had violated the company’s confidentiality policy after it dismissed his claims. https://t.co/zdvrhRCJZo
The Supreme Court ruled a high-school football coach who lost his job after praying on the 50-yard line had a constitutional right to publicly exercise his faith https://t.co/fN4H2dV4jX
U.S. intelligence agencies would be permitted to hire job applicants who have used marijuana in the past, under a bill that passed a Senate committee https://t.co/aDP8Gsc2RR

The Group of Seven club of wealthy democracies is inching toward an agreement on expanding its sanctions against Russia by looking for a mechanism to cap the purchase price of Russian oil https://t.co/dnpwdSZIh9
Ukraine is looking to recapture a city crucial for its economy and stop Russian designs on advancing to the doorstep of Europe https://t.co/XfTJzqewEk
EVs are a way to sidestep soaring gas prices—but it’ll cost you. The average price paid for an EV in the U.S. in May rose 22% from a year earlier. https://t.co/Yln2iv3hQY
The U.S. held secret meeting in March of Israeli and Arab military chiefs on air defense coordination against Iran https://t.co/NCA237c6x1

One person died and four were injured, including a 7-year-old girl and her mother, after a Russian missile hit a residential building in Kyiv Sunday, Ukrainian national police said https://t.co/kuOggKcAMm

Heightened scrutiny both inside and outside Boeing in recent years has revealed a number of production flaws and largely prevented the company from delivering new Dreamliner jets for nearly two years. Here's what's holding the 787 back. https://t.co/YOiqY76yTb
Watch: When inflation began to rise in 2021, it was confined to certain sectors of the economy. Now rising prices are everywhere. https://t.co/EmUVM35zpZ
Companies are laying fiber-optic cable in the Arctic as global warming melts the ice plates. Countries, meanwhile, are vying for geopolitical advantage. https://t.co/CFnV0SfxWf

From @WSJopinion: The test of a Fed Chairman isn’t when rates are falling. It’s when rates are rising, and unemployment rises too. That’s when Americans will find out if Jerome Powell has the starch for the job. https://t.co/disOrQsRfz
Three years ago, Anna Weyant’s drawings were selling for $400 on the beach. Now the 27-year-old is an art star whose paintings sold for nearly $4 million combined at auction. https://t.co/yCtTkcja3c
Toyota is recalling all of its new battery-powered sport-utility vehicles after finding the wheels could potentially fall off because of issues with bolts https://t.co/wRNpCHDzdY

The killings of two Jesuit priests last Monday, which led Pope Francis, himself a Jesuit, to bemoan Mexico’s unrelenting violence, underscore how Mexican organized crime groups rule over huge swaths of the country’s territory https://t.co/twBXeTbOhH
The U.S. and allies have laid out plans to invest billions of dollars for infrastructure projects in developing countries in an attempt to challenge China https://t.co/7RXj5oxyBX
A global drive for a minimum corporate tax rate is facing resistance in Hungary and the U.S. Congress https://t.co/upUicKlCRJ
Hubris, greed and leverage. How the crypto industry grew to wild heights, and what the reckoning looks like. https://t.co/7Bh8yLEPtJ
The U.S. will join other leading countries in banning Russian gold imports, broadening a sanctions regime against Moscow as an international summit is set to begin Sunday https://t.co/wrmk5V5bjG
Russia is poised to default on its foreign debt for the first time since 1918, pushed into delinquency not for lack of money but because of Western sanctions https://t.co/3bvzDFlCot
